Title: Bounding the integral $\int_{2}^{x} \frac{\mathrm dt}{\log^{n}{t}}$
Content: If $x \geq 2$, then how do we prove that $$\int_{2}^{x} \frac{\mathrm dt}{\log^{n}{t}} = O\Bigl(\frac{x}{\log^{n}{x}}\Bigr)?$$
AcceptedAnswer: Here is a way to prove it without knowing the answer before hand. Let $c > 2$ be a number such that $c > e^{n+1}$. It is enough to consider $$\int_{c}^{x} \frac{dt}{\log^n t}$$ Integrating by parts, we get $$\int_{c}^{x} \frac{dt}{\log^n t} =  \frac{x}{\log^n x} - K + n \int_{c}^{x} \frac{dt}{\log^{n+1} t}$$ Now $$n\int_{c}^{x} \frac{dt}{\log^{n+1} t} \le \frac{n}{n+1} \int_{c}^{x} \frac{dt}{\log^n t} $$ as $\log t \ge n+1$ for $t \ge c$ Thus $$\frac{1}{n+1}\int_{c}^{x} \frac{dt}{\log^n t} < \frac{x}{\log^n x}  $$ In fact, we have that $$\int_{2}^{x} \frac{dt}{\log^n t} = \theta(\frac{x}{\log^n x})$$
